page.title: 12The Village Hall, Stoulton
page.content: The village hall plays an important part in community life in Stoulton. The hall was built in 1877 as a village school until there were too few Stoulton children to keep it open. It then closed in 1933. The children now travel to the school at Drakes Broughton. The hall belongs to the church and the Parish Council pays a "peppercorn" rent. It is built of red brick with a tiled roof. The hall provides a pleasant, central meeting place in the village and is frequently used for a wide and expanding range of activities including whist drives, dog training classes, Woman Institute meetings, Parochial Church and Parish Council meetings, harvest suppers and other social events. However, local people seemed envious of the new village hall at Norton which is bigger.
